'''World Naked Gardening Day''' ('''WNGD''')<ref name=marinij>{{cite news |title= Fine Living: Nude gardening buffs exposed|author= |url= http://www.marinij.com/homeandgarden/ci_5823997|newspaper=[[Marin Independent Journal]] |date= 5 March 2007|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> is an annual international event celebrated on the first Saturday of May<ref name="msnbc naked"> {{cite news |title= Not dirty to play in dirt on World Naked Gardening Day|author= Laura T. Coffey|url= http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/43018053/ns/today-today_people/#.T2clA9nTAwc|newspaper= MSNBC|date= 13 April 2011|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Metropolitan home">{{cite book|title=Metropolitan home|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M-gJAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=21 March 2012|year=2008|publisher=Meredith Corp|page=64}}</ref> by [[gardening|gardeners]] and non-gardeners alike.<ref>{{cite news |title= Nude climber craze tipped to take over Britain|author= |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/2403752/Nude-climber-craze-tipped-to-take-over-Britain.html|newspaper= [[The Daily Telegraph]]|date= 14 July 2008|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> According to [[Today (U.S. TV program)|NBC's Today News]], WNGD "has become an annual tradition that celebrates [[weed control|weeding]], planting flowers and trimming hedges in the buff. While it's linked to a movement of [[naturism|nudists]] who promote wholesome and unashamed acceptance of the human body, the day is meant to be funny, lighthearted and non-political, founders say."<ref name = "NBC Today News">{{cite web|url = http://www.today.com/id/43018053/ns/today-today_people/#.UwK2l3n5L8E|title = Not dirty to play in dirt on World Naked Gardening Day: Saturday's global movement celebrates weeding, planting flowers in the buff|author= Laura T. Coffey|publisher = [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today News]]|date = May 13, 2011|accessdate = February 17, 2014}}</ref> [[File:Woman Gardening Naked.jpg|thumb|A naked woman marks the outline of a raised bed in a private backyard on World Naked Gardening Day]] [[File:World Naked Gardening Day.jpg|thumb|A graphic for a gardening video celebrating World Naked Gardening Day in 2016.]]
==Organization==
WNGD was founded and is organized by [[Mark Storey]], consulting editor for [[Nude & Natural]] magazine and [[permaculture|permaculturalist]] Jacob Gabriel, as a project of Body Freedom Collaborative (BFC). In its early days, Mark Storey had a vision of BFC engaging in "guerrilla pranksterism"<ref>[[Nude & Natural]] (N), ''Guerilla Nudity/Wave Makers: Introducing the Body Freedom Collaborative'' by Mark Storey. Issue 23.1, Autumn 2003.</ref> such as hopping out of a van or showing up spontaneously in an urban environment and engaging in [[guerilla gardening]].
Storey is the current project lead and he introduced the concept to readers of [[Nude & Natural]] magazine in 2005 and follow-up stories in later years in the same magazine. Corky Stanton, of Clothes Free International, who was also providing web hosting for [[World Naked Bike Ride]] at that time, supported the effort with web site hosting and promotion from the beginning of the project.
In the [[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]], Mark Storey notes that WNGD is not owned by any one organization. "No particular organization owns World Naked Gardening Day," Storey said, and it's not actually one large gathering of horticulturists in [[Seattle]] who strip down and shear some shrubs together."<ref name="NYdailynews"> {{cite news |title= World Naked Gardening Day encourages no-pants planting|author= Victoria Taylor|url= http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/world-naked-gardening-day-digging-article-1.1335126|newspaper= [[NY Daily News]]|date= 4 May 2013|accessdate=17 Feb 2014}}</ref>
While the phenomenon quickly spread internationally, little investment has been made by its founders. "Storey said he and Johnson<ref name="Gabriel" group="Note">Daniel Johnson changed his name to Jacob Gabriel in 2013.</ref> haven't spent any money or gone to any great lengths to promote World Naked Gardening Day since they initiated it. They helped create a website early on, and then receded into the background. They intended that the idea of an introduction to clothes freedom through gardening was valuable and would grow organically on its own."<ref name = "NBC Today News"/>
==Fixing the date of the event==
WNGD was inspired by a combination of Gabriel's and Storey's involvement in and inspiration by the success of [[World Naked Bike Ride]], the first of which was held internationally in 2004<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/life/lifestyle/world-naked-gardening-day-it-all-started-in-seattle|title=World Naked Gardening Day: It all started in Seattle|last=Lacitis|first=Erik|date=2017-05-07|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2017-05-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> and the enjoyment and simplicity of Storey's experience with his wife, gardening naked in the backyard as well as his experience [[naked hiking]] and kayaking. The first annual World Naked Gardening Day event took place on September 10, 2005.<ref name="msnbc naked"/> In 2007, the event date was moved to the first Saturday in May where it still takes place to this day.<ref name="dates" group="Note">Previously, WNGD has taken place on September 10, 2005, 1st Annual; Saturday, September 9, 2006, 2nd Annual; Saturday, May 5, 2007, 3rd Annual (date switched to May for first time, first Saturday); Saturday, May 3, 2008, 4th Annual; Saturday, May 2, 2009, 5th Annual; Saturday, May 8, 2010, 6th Annual; Saturday, May 14, 2011, 7th Annual (accidentally set to 2nd Sat instead of first); Saturday, May 5, 2012, 8th Annual; Saturday, May 4, 2013, 9th Annual.</ref> The event takes place the day before International Permaculture Day, which takes place on the first Sunday of May.
Summer dates have been suggested due to colder [[temperate climate]] temperatures in May, to coincide with a joint [[World Naked Bike Ride]] event and for other reasons.<ref name="summer" group="Note">In November of 2010, Gabriel suggested the idea of changing the date of WNGD to coincide with the All-Earth Holiday, Dachnik Day or Gardener's Day on July 23 as he was currently interested in the Anastasia movement of the Ringing Cedars book series, written by Siberian entrepreneur [[Vladimir Megre]]. This was a popular book within [[raw veganism]] and [[permaculture]] circles Gabriel was involved in at the time. Gabriel was also hoping to gain a warmer date for the event since May is often much cooler in [[temperate climates]]. Despite his interest, Gabriel was often not directly participating in events due to the cool Seattle May weather. He was also thinking that there could be a combination of both WNGD and the [[World Naked Gardening Day#Gardens Everywhere Bike Parade|Gardens Everywhere Bike Parade]] to fill a strategic warm-weather date slot in the [[World Naked Bike Ride Seattle]] and [[social nudity in Seattle|Seattle social nudity]] event schedule. The idea for the date change and Dachnik Day affiliation never had much momentum and Gabriel later soundly rejected interest in the Ringing Cedars book and its overt [[new age]] ideas when he became a [[Born again (Christianity)|born-again Christian]] in the years soon after.</ref> But WNGD is about gardening, and gardeners know that spring is a key time to nurture plants. Also, WNGD may be enjoyed both indoors and outside.
In 2018, the New Zealand Naturist Federation adopted the last weekend in October, that was better suited to the southern hemisphere climate.<ref name="New Zealand Naturist Federation June 2018">{{closed access}} {{cite |title=Gardening au naturel |journal=Gonatural |publisher=New Zealand Naturist Federation |date=June 2018 |issue=245 |issn=1177-1887 |oclc=173322430 |url=https://gonatural.co.nz/gonatural-magazine/past-issues/ |subscription=yes}}</ref> Horticulture supplier Yates supported the event and supplied Swan Plant seedlings.
==Motivation==
According to the organizers, "besides being liberating, nude gardening is second only to swimming as an activity that people are most ready to consider doing nude," an assertion described as "true" by ''[[The Hamilton Spectator]]''.<ref name=spec>{{cite news |title= World naked gardening day|author= |url= http://www.thespec.com/news/article/531601--world-naked-gardening-day|newspaper= [[The Hamilton Spectator]]|date= 13 May 2011|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> The organization's website claims people throughout the world are "invited to tend their portion of the world's garden clothed as nature intended."<ref>{{cite news |title= Gardening naked as the end approaches|author= |url= http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110515/NEWS/105150332|newspaper= [[Mail Tribune]]|date= 15 May 2011|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref>
WNGD is endorsed by [[The Naturist Society]], Clothes Free International and [[American Association for Nude Recreation]] (AANR),<ref name="cleveland naked"> {{cite news |title= World Naked Gardening Day: Ready the soil, plant seeds and take off your clothes|author= |url= http://www.cleveland.com/insideout/index.ssf/2011/05/post_55.html|newspaper= [[The Plain Dealer|Cleveland.com]]|date= 11 May 2011|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> among others. Storey is the co-founder and current project lead of WNGD and moderates the WNGD Yahoo! Discussion group. Although the event is associated with the socio-cultural [[Naturism|naturist movement]], its founders assert the day is intended to be "lighthearted," and void of politics.<ref name="msnbc naked"/>
An AANR press release, published during the sixth annual World Naked Gardening Day, described naked gardening to be a healthy practice. AANR public relations representative Tom Mulhall claims naked gardening may help boost a positive [[self-image]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Have trowel, drop trou? – A nationwide day devoted to gardening in the nude doesn't seem to have gathered much traction in the Midwest.|author= |url= https://www.webcitation.org/66HnIdZa0|newspaper= [[Star Tribune]]|date= 12 May 2011 |accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref>
Beyond [[body image]], "Stanton cited fringe benefits of bare, unabashed recreation: the satisfaction of exercising in the great outdoors; the attractiveness of an all-over [[sunbathing|tan]]; more [[vitamin D]] on your whole body; the unbeatable experience of [[skinny-dipping]] if the naturist event involves a beach or a lake."<ref name = "NBC Today News"/>
==Private vs. public observance==
While the event is most often done in secluded areas, such as at home, BFC first kicked off the event with its trademark "guerrilla pranksterism" and did a photo shoot for the project's web site in a public park. In another year Storey and Gabriel enlisted the help of local free beach users at an unofficial clothing-optional beach park on [[Lake Washington]], in [[Seattle]]. Storey has also suggested that some remote hiking location would be quiet enough to host a trail cleanup.<ref name = "NBC Today News"/>
Many people chose not to venture beyond the relative safety of non-public areas. "It's not about exposing your body to other people," said Corky Stanton, of Clothes Free International, an organization that promotes nude recreation. "It's about body acceptance and being one with nature on your own. ... We actually do these events in secluded areas,"<ref name = "NBC Today News"/>
During the fifth annual World Naked Gardening Day in the United Kingdom, celebrated in 2010, organizers encouraged people to go naked either in their private gardens or in [[Urban park|public park]]s. According to the [[Sky News Online]], organizers of the event thought an "''au naturel joie de vivre''" will bind all communities and people regardless of their background and age.<ref>{{cite news |title= Phwoar-ticultural: It's Naked Gardening Day|author= |url= http://news.sky.com/home/strange-news/article/15627988|newspaper= [[Sky News Online]]|date= 8 May 2010|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref>
==Gardens Everywhere Bike Parade== In 2009, inspired by the success of both [[World Naked Bike Ride Seattle]] and WNGD, along with being inspired by his [[permaculture]] schooling at the time, Gabriel founded the Gardens Everywhere Bike Parade (GEBP), with co-organizer Kelda [[Lorax]], a local permaculture designer, advocate, and instructor.<ref name="Kelda" group="Note">At the time, Kelda Lorax went by the name Kelda Miller and she was one of Gabriel's Permaculture Design Course instructors. She is believed to have changed her name sometime around 2013.</ref> It was Kelda who came up with the GEBP name for the event. The ride in part was to take the simplicity and theme of gardening in WNGD and take it more public and deeper into principles of permaculture. The [[clothing-optional bike ride]] showcased local [[permaculture]] projects as well as general permaculture principles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mygreenlake.com/2009/08/gardens-everywhere-naked-bike-parade/|title=mygreenlake.com|publisher=|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> This same year Gabriel was involved in co-founding the [[Beacon Food Forest]], the first known [[food forest]] on public lands.
The Ride launched from Om Culture in Wallingford, went East on the [[Burke-Gilman Trail]]. Local artist Franz and others had staged a body painting and art bike decorating party at that location. The ride then headed North on [[The Ave]] and toured the [[University District, Seattle|University District]], stopped at the University District Farmer's Market and University Heights [[P-Patch]] at the University Heights Center. A tour was given by Kelda and the [[rainwater harvesting]] system was highlighted.
It continued up the Ave to a Shiga's Community Garden, which is also a Seattle Department of Neighborhoods Community Garden. At this time the garden was being cleared of invasive weeds left over from a vacant lot into future planting in 2010. By coincidence volunteers were clearing that lot and GEBP helped the group for a few minutes carry out invasive weeds. The [[Seattle Police]] responded at Shiga's Garden from a complaint from the stop at the University Farmer's Market and left when the officers where reassured that riders were not going back to the market.
The ride then left traveled North to [[Thrive Cafe|Thrive]] restaurant and enjoyed gourmet [[raw veganism|raw vegan food]] prepared by the restaurant staff for the riders. The ride continued to Roosevelt P-Patch and dropped in on a friends garden in the area. The ride continued through the Roosevelt district to Permaculturist Jenny Pell's house, then to [[Mighty-O Donuts]] in the [[Meridian, Seattle|Tangletown]] neighborhood, where the group serenaded, unsuccessfully the workers for donuts. The ride continued to a tour of [[Seattle Tilth]] at the [[Home of the Good Shepherd]], took a tour of the grounds and surprised a wedding party taking place in the area bordering Meridian Playground and the Good Shephard Center.
After leaving Meridian Playground, the ride went to an intersection repair<ref group="Note" name="intersection repair">Intersection repair is a term coined by the [[City Repair Project]], based in Portland, Oregon, and is essentially an artistic, whimsical, painted mural on the street aimed at slowing traffic and building interest in local neighborhood community building.</ref> done with a mural of a giant [[ladybug]]. The Wallingford Ladybug, known as Wallybug, is located at the intersection of N 49th Street and Burke Ave N in Wallingford. It was created in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.travelmarx.com/2012/05/wallingford-ladybug-intersection.html|title=TravelMarx|publisher=|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> The group then stopped in front of a residence where the homeowners were gardening in their front parking strip and the group sang for them. Another stop was made at a residence offering refreshments to riders, another stop at a neighbor selling [[Organic food|organic]] [[Heirloom plant|heirloom]] produce from her yard and the ride ended at a private residence for a clothing-optional party in a backyard gardening featuring a handmade cobb [[masonry oven]].
A fundraising film party was held at [[Thrive Cafe|Thrive]] Cafe on September 9, 2009, which showed footage of the event collected by the riders and photographers.
==Cultural references== In 2013, Ritchie Duncan, contributor to [[TruTV|TruTv's]] Dumb as a Blog, suggested a hybrid event, "World Naked '[[Star Wars]]' Gardening Day", encouraging readers to tweet their pictures to @DumbasaBlog with the hashtag #nakedstarwarsgardening. He joked that participants could say "May the fourth be with you,", in a nod to the date of the hybrid World Naked 'Star Wars' Gardening Day, which would occur that year (May 4, 2013), the same as the date of [[Star Wars Day]] (May Fourth) and the popular Star Wars expression "[[May the Force be with you]]."
One suggested idea was "Get naked and paint your face red and black like [[Darth Maul]]. Attach another rake to the handle of your existing rake for "nude double lightsaber raking action."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blog.trutv.com/dumb-as-a-blog/2013/05/03/naked-star-wars-gardening-tomorrow-whos-in/index.html|title = Naked Star Wars gardening Saturday? Who's in?|date = May 3, 2013}}</ref> The blog author, Duncan, joked he has not though much of which franchise characters he would like to see naked gardening but joked, "I'd hate to have [[George Lucas]] digitally add clothes later."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/03/world-naked-star-wars-gardening-day_n_3210730.html|title = World Naked 'Star Wars' Gardening Day Is May 4|accessdate = February 17, 2014|publisher = ''[[The Huffington Post]]''|last = Moye|first = David}}</ref>
==Notable and historical naked gardening== [[Adam and Eve]] were noted to garden naked, before [[the fall of man]], in the [[Book of Genesis]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
[[Hesiod]] exhorts farmers: "When the Atlas-born Pleiades rise, start the harvest—the plowing, when they set . . . This is the rule for the plains, and for those who dwell near the sea and those far from the swelling sea in the valleys and glens, fertile land: sow naked, and plow naked, and harvest naked, if you want to bring in all of Demeter's works in due season, so that each crop may grow for you in its season. " The Pleiades rise in early May and set in November.<ref>Hesiod. Works and Days. Lines 383-394. Edited and translated by Glenn W. Most. Loeb Classical Library 57. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2007</ref>
[[Edna St. Vincent Millay]] was known to garden nude at the Steepletop estate in New York as part of her [[Bohemianism|Bohemian]] lifestyle.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
[[Walt Whitman]] is also known to have written about his naked experiences in nature. In Specimen Day he wrote: "Sweet, sane, still Nakedness in Nature! --ah if poor, sick, prurient humanity in cities might really know you once more! Is not nakedness then indecent? No, not inherently. It is your thought, your sophistication, your fear, your respectability that is indecent. There come moods when these clothes of ours are not only too irksome to wear, but are themselves indecent. Perhaps indeed he or she to whom the free exhilarating ecstasy of nakedness in Nature has never been eligible (and how many thousands there are!) has not really known what purity is--nor what faith or art or health really is."
Actress and [[PETA]] spokesperson, [[Alicia Silverstone]], in an interview with [[Health (magazine)|Health magazine]] said "It probably started when I was doing my garden the first time. I'd be out there, and it would be scorching hot, so I would take off all of my clothes and garden. And then I would jump in the pool and swim - and I always get in the pool naked, because why would you want to put on a bathing suit?"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.health.com/health/article/0,,20411948_2,00.html|title = Alicia Silverstone: How a Vegan Diet Makes You Sparkle: Alicia Silverstone dishes on vegan diets, having children, and gardening naked.|date = August 19, 2009|accessdate = February 17, 2014|publisher = Health magazine|first = Amy|last = Spencer}}</ref>
One month prior to the first WNGD event on September 10, 2005, Ian and Barbara Pollard, resident gardening experts on ITV's '' [[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]'', held its first "clothes optional day" at [[Abbey House Gardens]] in [[Malmesbury, Wiltshire|Malmesbury]], [[Wiltshire]], [[England]].
''[[The New York Times]]'' ran an article about naked gardening neighbors next-door.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/21/garden/the-nakeds-next-door.html|title=The Nakeds Next Door|date=21 November 2013|publisher=|accessdate=10 February 2016|via=The New York Times}}</ref>
